text.p: The following are some of the leading stories in Finnish papers this morning.
HELSINGIN SANOMAT
- Finnish marketing reseach companies have gained a foothold in Russian and Estonian markets and are expanding their operations, sector representatives say.

- By saying that the powers of the president should not be limited, Finance Minister Sauli Niinisto and Justice Minister Kari Hakamies have changed their stances, says speaker of parliament Riitta Uosukainen.
- In the 1990s, Finnish politicians have discovered the value of women's magazines, and many politicians, especially members of the opposition, fear being forgotten and eagerly give interviews.
- A bear wandering around southwestern Finland has been seen approaching the Moomin Valley amusement park.
KAUPPALEHTI

- A stringent fiscal policy keeping long interest rates low and a moderate wage deal will help control economic growth during the next two years, says senior finance ministry official Martti Hetemaki.
- Competition between 'family retreat' businesses is growing ever tougher, sector representatives say.
- The State of Finland will not need to take extra loans this year, beyond those already planned, says deputy budget director at finance ministry.

- Abolishing shipping companies' rights to duty-free alcohol sales too quickly will create problems, and tax-free sales should be allowed beyond 1999, says deputy managing director at Helsinki Chambre of Commerce.
AAMULEHTI

- It would be odd to have a directly elected president with restricted powers, says Left Alliance party secretary Kari Laitinen, joining the debate over the proper scope of the powers of the Finnish president.
- Some young Finns shun work and prefer a free ride on social security benefits, a social worker says, calling for discussion of the topic.
- Police say they are catching more drunken drivers than before because motorists are reporting suspected cases by mobile phone.
TURUN SANOMAT
- The president's attendance at European Union summits is not well-reasoned, says Young Finns party MP Jukka Tarkka.
DEMARI
- The central issue of the government's budget talks central issue should be to defend low-income workers, says Second Finance Ninister Arja Alho, a social democrat.
HUFVUDSTADSBLADET
- International diabetes conference has brought some 9,000 diabetes experts from 132 countries to Helsinki this week.
-- Nora Hallberg, Helsinki Newsroom +358-9-680 50 292
